title: EFFECT OF CONFINEMENT ON SILICEOUS AGGREGATE CONCRETE SUBJECTED TO ELEVATED TEMPERATURES AND CYCLIC HEATING. DISCUSSION
authors: G. Baker; J. Stabler
abstract: A discussion of a paper with the aforementioned title by M.J. Terro and S.A. Hamoush, published in this journal (Volume 94, Number 2, March-April 1997), is presented. The discussers raise three issues. First, there is a solid body of experimental and numerical evidence to suggest that an initial stress inhibits thermal damage during heating, giving a substantial relative improvement in compressive strength. Second, nearly all of the stress-strain plots for temperatures beyond 200 deg C show an initially flat slope to the curve, followed by a steeper response before reaching the plastic limit. Finally, it would be valuable to explain fully the observation that heating cycles improve compressive strength above 300 deg C.

title: INFLUENCE OF FLY ASH ON SETTING AND HARDENING CHARACTERISTICS OF CONCRETE SYSTEMS. DISCUSSION
authors: H. H. Haynes
abstract: A discussion of a paper with the aforementioned title by T.R. Naik and S.S. Singh, published in this journal (Volume 94, Number 5, September-October 1997), is presented. The discusser maintains that the suggestion of using gypsum as an admixture to portland cement concrete is a significant error, because the two materials are not compatible.

title: LOW-CYCLE FATIGUE OF PLAIN AND FIBER-REINFORCED CONCRETE. DISCUSSION AND CLOSURE
authors: Leonard W. Bell
abstract: A discussion of a paper with the aforementioned title by T. Paskova and C. Meyer, published in this journal (Volume 94, Number 4, July-August 1997), is presented. The discussion points out that when an inert filler is added to concrete, the added surface area for cement paste to coat requires a mixture adjustment. Furthermore, the discusser questions the comparison of steel fibers with polypropylene fibers. Discussion is followed by closure from the authors.

title: BOND STRENGTH OF REINFORCEMENT IN HIGH-PERFORMANCE CONCRETE: ROLE OF SILICA FUME, CASTING POSITION, AND SUPERPLASTICIZER DOSAGE. DISCUSSION
authors: M Reze Esfahani
abstract: A discussion of a paper with the aforementioned title by B.S. Hamad, and M.S. Itani, published in this journal (Volume 95, Number 5, September-October 1998), is presented. The discussion analyzes the published test results and evaluates the effect of silica fume and superplasticizers on bond strength. The discusser shows that the addition of silica fume in the concrete mix does not have a negative effect on bond strength and contends that the opposite conclusion was obtained by the authors because of two problems: the concrete compressive strength of specimens without silica fume was smaller than that of specimens with silica fume; and the authors did not consider that the bond stress distribution influences the bond strength. The discusser believes that, instead of normalized loads, the absolute value of loads should be used to compare the beam stiffness.

title: TENSILE BEHAVIOR OF SLURRY INFILTRATED MAT CONCRETE (SIMCON). DISCUSSION AND CLOSURE
authors: Ajiboye F. Oluokun
abstract: A discussion of a paper with the aforementioned title by N. Krstulovic and S. Malak, published in this journal (Volume 94, Number 1, January-February 1997), is presented. The discussion raises questions concerning some of the equations developed and proposed by the paper's authors in which the aspect ratio appeared as a variable, since test results were based on specimens containing fiber mats fabricated from 9.5 in (241.3 mm) long fibers only, where the aspect ratio of the fibers had a constant value of 713. Based on this, the discusser disagrees with the models presented for the tensile strength and toughness. Discussion is followed by closure from the authors.

title: A NEW RHEOMETER FOR SOFT-TO-FLUID FRESH CONCRETE. DISCUSSIONS AND CLOSURE
authors: Pfg Banfill; G. H. Tattersall
abstract: Two discussions of a paper with the aforementioned title by F. de Larrard, C. Hu, T. Sedran, J.C. Szitkar, M. Joly, F. Claux, and F. Derkx, published in this journal (Volume 94, Number 3, May-June 1997), are presented. The first discussion claims that the choice of parallel-plate geometry is fundamentally flawed, because the stress is a function of the radius, so that there would be some place where the concrete is not shared. The second discusser claims that as part of an attempted justification of their decision to develop a new apparatus, the authors make several incorrect statements about the two-point apparatus that was developed at the University of Sheffield. Discussions are followed by closure from the authors.

title: EFFECTS OF POLYSACCHARIDE GUM ADDITIVES ON SHOTCRETE PROCESS. DISCUSSION AND CLOSURE
authors: John J. Warner
abstract: A discussion of a paper with the aforementioned title by V.A. Ghio, and P.J.M. Monteiro, published in this journal (Volume 95, Number 2, March-April 1998), is presented. The discusser points out the importance of the material pressure at the pump outlet to produce a successful shotcrete job and questions exactly where and how the pressure values in the paper were taken. Discussion is followed by closure from the authors.

title: SENSITIVITY OF COMPRESSIVE STRENGTH OF HIGH-STRENGTH CONCRETE TO HOT-DRY CLIMATE, CURING REGIMES, AND ADDITIVES. DISCUSSION
authors: M.N. Haque
abstract: A discussion of a paper with the aforementioned title by S.H. Alsayed, published in this journal (Volume 94, Number 6, November-December 1997), is presented. The discussion offers additional comments that enhance the paper's conclusions on the effects of inadequate curing on the physical, mechanical, and durability characteristics of high-strength concrete. The adverse effects of hot-dry exposure conditions concomitant with lack of adequate curing of concrete do not seem to manifest well in the first 28 days.

title: USE OF RECLAIMED ASPHALT PAVEMENT AS AN AGGREGATE IN PORTLAND CEMENT CONCRETE. DISCUSSION
authors: John Wojakowski
abstract: A discussion of a paper with the aforementioned title by M. Delwar, M. Fahmy, and R. Taha, published in this journal (Volume 94, Number 3, May-June 1997), is presented. The discussion focuses on a recent Federal Highway Administration Kansas research project for high-performance concrete pavement that incorporated reclaimed asphalt pavement (RAP) into the mixture. It appears that using the scalped RAP for midsized aggregate may be viable for using waste material and filling holes in the gradation.

title: BOND STRENGTH OF REINFORCING BARS IN REINFORCED SHOTCRETE. DISCUSSION AND CLOSURE
authors: James Warner
abstract: A discussion of a paper with the aforementioned title by V.A. Ghio and P.J.M. Monteiro, published in this journal (Volume 94, Number 2, March-April 1997), is presented. The discusser points out that minor amounts of low density material as well as occasional air pockets and voids do become entrapped in heavily reinforced elements constructed with shotcrete on a production basis. Thus, he concludes that in order to minimize rebar congestion, lap splices generally should be avoided and mechanical splices used. Discussion is followed by closure from the authors.

title: SHRINKAGE CRACKING OF HIGH-STRENGTH CONCRETE. DISCUSSION
authors: Emmanuel K. Attiogbe
abstract: A discussion of a paper with the aforementioned title by K. Wiegrink, S. Marikunte, and S.P. Shah, published in this journal (Volume 93, Number 5, September-October 1996), is presented. The discussion maintains that, in addition to factors such as higher free shrinkage, lower specific creep, higher modulus of elasticity, and lower aggregate interlock along crack faces, microcracking as a result of self-desiccation may also be an important factor in the higher rate of increase of crack width during the first few days for high-strength concrete compared with normal strength concrete.

title: EXPERIMENTAL STUDY OF PLAIN CONCRETE UNDER TRIAXIAL STRESS. DISCUSSION
authors: Ranga Palaniswamy; S P Shah
abstract: A discussion of a paper with the aforementioned title by I. Imran and S.J. Pantazopoulou, published in this journal (Volume 93, Number 6, November-December 1996), is presented. The discussers report on an earlier study they conducted, which addressed both failure and deformation characteristics, as opposed to the authors' study, which emphasized more the strength/failure aspects rather than the deformation characteristics.

title: TOLERANCES INVOLVING REINFORCING BARS
authors: Fisher
abstract: This paper deals with the tolerances that affect reinforcing bars both in fabrication and placing. The paper defines the current reinforcing bar tolerances as found in the industry and ACI standards. Comparisons are made between these tolerances. Examples of current tolerance requirements are presented. Concluding the paper are several possible approaches future tolerancing practices and standards may take.

title: DURABILITY OF SOME GLASS FIBER REINFORCED CEMENT COMPOSITES
authors: J Eijen
abstract: A number of glass fiber reinforced cement composites currently on the market were investigated with regard to the alteration of mechanical properties over time. Among these were several so-called alkali-resistant glass fibers (AR-GFRC) and a system consisting of E-glass fibers with a polymer-modified cement matrix (Forton (P)GFRC) . Properties such as strain at ultimate tensile stress, bending strength, and impact strength were initially higher for the AR-GRFC than for the (P)GFRC. However, the AR-GFRC system showed a considerable decrease of these properties over time, resulting over the long term in a lower level than for (P)GFRC.

title: FRACTURE PROPERTIES AND BRITTLENESSS OF HIGH-STRENGTH CONCRETE
authors: Ravindra Gettu; Z. P. Bažant; Martha E. Karr
abstract: The size effect method for determining material fracture characteristics, as previously proposed by Bazant is applied to typical high-strength concrete. Geometrically similar 3-point bending specimens are tested and the measured peak load values are used to obtain the fracture energy, the fracture toughness, the effective length of the fracture process zone, and the effective critical crack tip opening displacement. The brittleness of the material is shown to be objectively quantified through the size-effect method. Comparing the material fracture properties obtained with those of normal strength concrete shows that an increase of 16 % in compressive srength causes: (1) increase of fracture toughness; (2) decrease of effective fracture process zone length; (3) more than doubling of the brittleness number. The brittleness number, however, is still not high enough to permit the use of linear elastic fracture mechanics. The R-curves are demonstrated to derive according to the size effect law exclusively from the maximum loads of specimens of various sizes and yield remarkably good predictions of the load-deflection curves.

title: ALTERNATE METHOD TO MEASURE AIR CONTENT IN FRESH CONCRETE
authors: Kamal H. Khayat; K. W. Nasser; Weston T. Hester
abstract: The correlations of air content measurements obtained with a new airmeter, called the mini air meter, and two other ASTM standard air meters were examined to establish the reliability of the new apparatus. The details are described of the mini air meter which uses the volumetric principle to determine the air content of fresh concrete. The laboratory work involved testing the air content of 21 concrete mixtures using the mini, roller, and pressure air meters. The water-cementitious materials ratios of the mixes ranged between 0.22 and 0.51. The cement content varied from 450 to 10 lb/ cubic yard, with silica fume added to some mixes. All mixes incorporated superplasitcizers, and air-entraining agents. The study results are presented and discussed.

title: DYNAMIC TESTS OF A TIME-SPACE MODEL OF COMPLEX TRAVEL BEHAVIOR
authors: Will Recker; T F Golobv; Michael G. McNally; John D. Leonard
abstract: Research is reported, which focuses on developing procedures for the dynamic analysis of possible changes in activity patterns that may result from or lead to changes in the characteristics of the household. It attempts to analyze the entire daily activity pattern simultaneously in terms of its space, time, and activity category dimensions. The study traced the daily activity patterns of groups of travelers that have undergone significant change during multiple points in time, in a manner that will shed some light on both the nature and extent of associated changes in travel behavior. Complementary analyses of pattern attributes, and time-series analyses of patterns were performed on the same data set to check on the reliability of the modeling process and to understand its peculiarities.

title: ISSUES ON TRANSPORT IN LATIN-AMERICAN CITIES
authors: Óscar Figueroa; Étienne Henry
abstract: The organization of public transport in Latin-American cities is burdened with many social and economic issues. These issues play an important part in the urban structuralization modes of a region which today is largely urban and comprised of cities which rank among the principal municipalities in the world. On a sectorial basis, these issues concern mass transit systems, the large ones, but for the most part the numerous small bus and minibus operations, policies practiced by the different levels of public powers, and urban mobility. The effort on synthesis undertaken here aims firstly to clarify, from the specialized literature, the paradigms arising from the conceptual approaches of these issues, comparing viewpoints of different researchers and experts. Later, a diagnosis of the system crisis, is introduced, reviewing, for the main urban conurbations of the region, the noticeable effects on management and operation of services and on trip conditions of social groups. The synthesis emerges onto a proposal of an analytical scheme based on the intrinsic features of principal social agents and on their relations in the evolutive systems.

title: EARLY-AGE BOND STRENGTH IN REINFORCED CONCRETE. TECHNICAL PAPER. TITLE NO. 84.M44
authors: R. Chapman; S P Shar
abstract: An investigation was conducted to determine the bond strength between reinforcing steel and concrete loaded at early ages. Bond tests were conducted using a specially developed pullout test. Load-slip characteristics of smooth and deformed bars were compared for specimens with different bar-embedment lengths and tested at various ages from 1 to 28 days of curing. Smooth bars did not exhibit any age effect. However, the bond characteristics of deformed bars showed a significant age effect. It was observed that the ACI Building Code-suggested equation for development length overestimated test results for very early ages. An alternate relationship is examined for structures loaded at early ages.

title: THIS PAPER PRESENTS COMPREHENSIVE INFORMATION ON THE
authors: R.N. Swamy; M M Al-Asali
abstract: This paper preesnts comprehensive information on the expansion of concrete undergoing alkali-silica reaction (ASR). Both beltane opal and a synthetic-fused silica were used as reactive aggregates, and the cement used was a portland cement with about 1 % sodium oxide equivalent by weight. The effects of temperature, cement content, and the presence of alkali from sources other than cement on the expansion of concrete are reported. It is shown that when all the alkali is cement bound, an alkali content of 3 to 4 kg/m cubed represents a critical band of alkalinity above and below which either a dramatic increase or decrease of expansion occurs. When, in addition external sources of alkali are also present, this range of total alkalinity represents a threshold value above which expansion again increases dramatically irrespective of the source of alkalinity. When the reactive aggregate is of the type of fused silica, the maximum tolerable alkalinity is about 2.0 kg/m cubed if disruptive expansion and cracking are to be avoided. The results showed no relation between expansion and popouts.

title: CORROSION OF STEEL IN CONCRETE MADE WITH SLAG CEMENT. TECHNICAL PAPER. TITLE NO 84-M47
authors: B.B. Hope; Akc Ip
abstract: The effect of slag cement on corrosion of steel in concrete was investigated. Reinforced concrete slabs containing different proportions of slag and portland cement were subjected to various cycles of wetting and drying by soaking in an air-saturated 3.5 percent sodium chloride solution and drying in laboratory air. Corrosion of steel was examined electrochemically and visually. Concrete electrical resistivity and chloride measurements were conducted. Corrosion of the steel rods in the concretes decreased with increase in slag content except during the first seven days after casting. This was accompanied by a corresponding higher concrete electrical resistivity and lower chloride diffusion rate. The electrical resistivities of concretes made with slag cement appeared to be more sensitive to a change in storage condition than that of portland cement concretes.
